subNodes.conversationText: root
The Minister of Peace had just emerged from the king's tent. He had a sheaf of papers is in his hands.
[Continue.]

"You're back!" He was surprised. Then, more quietly: "We can't keep this under wraps much longer. People have been asking about the king. They haven't heard him snoring. These -- " he held out the papers  "are letters I have to send as soon as we hear from Princess Zidae. Apologies, I'm quite busy. What did you want?"
"Minister, I have some bad news about Astimund." [Reveal Astimund's plan.]
The minister fixed his eyes on <FirstName>.
[Continue.]
"Oh?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> revealed Astimund's scheme -- the two forged letters, the plan to delay the coronation until the embassy had reached Dudow, his hope that <FirstName> would help.
[Continue.]
"Outrageous! Treason! Treachery!" spluttered the minister. "You can prove this, yes? Do you have the forgeries?"
"No. I refused the offer before he gave them to me."
"Of course, of course. Where is he? I'll have his head." Despite <FirstName>'s lack of proof, the minister clearly believed <him/her>.
[Continue.]

But Astimund was nowhere in sight. The royal encampment was not large, and the dangers of the woods meant that only scouts and soldiers wandered far from it. But after a few inquiries and an examination of his tent, it was clear -- Astimund had fled. He had taken clothing, valuables, and documents. No one had seen him go. The minister surmised that he had crept into the woods, hoping to come upon a friendly path in time.
[Continue.]
"Damn it! Gone. To Wan, no doubt. Well, let him die or defect. What do I care? But -- no. No! He might know things that would injure Dudow... I'll send soldiers after him."
[Continue.]

"Pardon me; thinking aloud. Thank you for bringing this to my attention. Curse him! But you -- You came to us -- no, to me -- at a most fateful moment, just like the witches in the stories. But now my work begins, my first task on behalf of the new queen. Dudow isn't safe with that spy at large. If you'll excuse me, I must speak with the captain."
"I hoped you would give me something in return for my honesty."
"Yes, of course... But what?" he mused. "Ah! Follow me."
[Continue.]
They went into Astimund's tent. Among the things he had left behind was a cloak with the symbol of Didow embroidered on it.
[Continue.]
"He decided he wouldn't need this in Wan. Go ahead, take it. It's very nice work and worth more than any trinket."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> took the cloak. It wasn't much, given the extraordinary nature of what <he/she>'d revealed to the minister. But it was better than nothing. Then the two parted ways.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch told the minister about Astimund's scheme. Then they discovered that the ambassador had fled -- most likely to Wan. Now the affair was out of the young witch's hands -- wasn't it?

subNodes.conversationText: "Of course. Farewell, Minister."

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch told the minister about Astimund's scheme. Then they discovered that the ambassador had fled -- most likely to Wan. Now the affair was out of the young witch's hands -- wasn't it?

subNodes.conversationText: "He said he was going to destroy them."
"Of course, of course. Where is he? I'll have his head." Despite <FirstName>'s lack of proof, the minister clearly believed <him/her>.
<FirstName> hesitated.
Should <he/she> tell the minister about the ambassador's scheme?
Yes.
The minister was waiting.
"Minister, I have some bad news about Astimund." [Reveal Astimund's plan.]
Again <he/she> doubted. No, <he/she> couldn't bring <him/her>self to do it.
"It's nothing," the young witch said to the ambassador.
[Continue.]
"Then I hope you'll pardon me. I haven't forgotten your vision, you know -- if anything, the king's death makes everything clearer. Have you seen Astimund, by the way?"
[Continue.]

It was true. Astimund was nowhere in sight. The royal encampment was not large, and the dangers of the woods meant that only scouts and soldiers wandered far from it.

If the ambassador had fled, maybe there was good reason to tell the minister the truth now.
"I have to tell you some bad news about Astimund."
"What? What do you mean?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> revealed Astimund's scheme -- the two forged letters, the plan to delay the coronation until the embassy had reached Dudow, his hope that <FirstName> would help.
[Continue.]
"This is outrageous! Treason! Treachery!" spluttered the minister. "You can prove this, yes? Do you have the letters?"
"No. I refused his offer before he gave them to me."
"Of course, of course. Where is he? I'll have his head." Despite <FirstName>'s lack of proof, the minister clearly believed <him/her>.
[Continue.]

After a few inquiries and an examination of his tent, it was clear -- Astimund had fled. He had taken clothing, valuables, and documents. No one had seen him go. The minister surmised that he had crept into the woods, hoping to come upon a friendly path in time.
[Continue.]
"He said he'd destroy them after I refused. If you can stop him --"
"Of course, of course. Where is he? I'll have his head." Despite <FirstName>'s lack of proof, the minister clearly believed <him/her>.
But no -- the young witch had made <his/her> decision. "I haven't seen him."
"He must be in his tent. Well, <FirstName>, good luck in your travels. May your coven look kindly on our new queen."
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch decided not to tell the minister about the ambassador's scheme after all. Time would sort the situation out without the witch's involvement -- wouldn't it?

subNodes.conversationText: No.
"It's nothing," the young witch said to the ambassador.
Continue
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch decided not to tell the minister about the ambassador's scheme after all. Time and power would sort the situation out.
